name: DECISON PROCESSES

values.comments:
OPIM 290 is an intensive introduction to various scientific perspectives on the processes through which people make decisions. Perspectives covered include cognitive psychology of human problem-solving, judgment and choice, theories of rational judgment and decision, and the mathematical theory of games. Much of the material is technically rigorous. Prior or current enrollment in STAT 101 or the equivalent, although not required, is strongly recommended. 

Students commented that they really enjoyed the class. Many said that is has tremendous applicability to everyday life. 

Students noted that Professor Ruedy was an extremely enthusiastic lecturer. Furthermore, she was very accessible, approachable, and highly encourages student participation. 

Students note that this is “an excellent choice for OPIM concentrators and has ramifications for psychology and consumer behavior.” Though the work is challenging, the workload did not appear to be a burden.

OPIM 290 is an intensive introduction to various scientific perspectives on the processes through which people make decisions. Perspectives covered include cognitive psychology of human problem-solving, judgment and choice, theories of rational judgment and decision, and the mathematical theory of games. Much of the material is technically rigorous. Prior or current enrollment in STAT 101 or the equivalent, although not required, is strongly recommended. 

Students considered this a very interesting course and enjoyed the real life examples and applications. Some found it to be confusing at times. One student wrote: “It was an absolute pleasure to go to class and learn something new and awesome every day about my own thinking mechanisms.” 

Many felt that “Professor Simonsohn is a very interesting lecturer with a genuine interest in teaching.” He had the ability to keep students interested and present the material in a very intuitive way. Some of the students did mention that the course would benefit from more structure. 

Some students noted that the readings were long and a bit dry.
